property camber: float

Estimates the camber of the blade using a bezier curve. This is not as accurate because thickness is not defined on suction and pressure sides.

Returns:

turbodesign.bladerow.compute_gas_constants(row: BladeRow, fluid: Solution = None) → None[source]

Updates the Cp, Gamma, and density for a blade row. If fluid is not specified then only density and viscosity is updated.

Parameters:

  • row (BladeRow) – _description_

  • fluid (Solution, optional) – _description_. Defaults to None.

Returns:

updated row

Return type:

(BladeRow)

turbodesign.bladerow.interpolate_quantities(q: ndarray[tuple[int, ...], dtype[_ScalarType_co]], r: ndarray[tuple[int, ...], dtype[_ScalarType_co]], r2: ndarray[tuple[int, ...], dtype[_ScalarType_co]])[source]

Interpolates array q

Parameters:

  • q (npt.NDArray) – quantities defined at radius r

  • r (npt.NDArray) – radius where quantities q are defined

  • r2 (npt.NDArray) – new radius to interpolate the quantities to e.g. streamline radius

Returns:

quantities interpolated onto r2

Return type:

npt.NDArray

turbodesign.bladerow.interpolate_streamline_radii(row: BladeRow, passage: Passage, num_streamlines: int = 3)[source]

Interpolate all quantities onto the streamline and allocates variables. Run this after setting some initial conditions

Parameters:

  • r_streamline (npt.NDArray) – Radii describing the streamline

  • passage (Passage) – Passage object describing the geometry of the hub and shroud

  • num_streamlines (int) – number of streamlines to consider

Returns:

new row object with quantities interpolated

Return type:

(BladeRow)

turbodesign.bladerow.sutherland(T: float | ndarray[tuple[int, ...], dtype[_ScalarType_co]]) → float | ndarray[tuple[int, ...], dtype[_ScalarType_co]][source]

Sutherland viscosity calculation used for reynolds number

Parameters:

T (float) – Temperature in Kelvin

Returns:

Dynamic Viscosity (mu) in Pa*s
